Brutalsky Russian streetwear.Gangster rap socks.No Starbucks. No bucks .Marble is too cold to sit or sleep on.Russian clothes designers . Very sophisticated dresses.Much of the shopping has moved to the side aisles to sell non-brand cheap merchandise. And this used to be a high end mall.Matryoshkas sharing a shelf with water pipes although technically weed is illegal in Russia.Gold is sold at the government pegged price of 5000 rubbles per gram. As such it’s not a good investment and has no practical value since the ratio of women to men grows expontatially with new shipments of heavy weapons to Ukraine.A can of Fanta costs $2.5.Dr. Pepper Zero is about $4. There won’t be any new shipments.Empty tables of a fancy coffee shop by the bronze fountain.Nothing improves appetite better than war photography on the wall.Communist food . I like .More communist food and a glimpse of the future.The closure of McDonald’s free toilets opened up a new niche: paid toilets. Three dollars for a can of Fanta and a dollar to piss.I used to come here on August 2nd, Paratrooper’s Day. to watch drunk paratroopers frolic in the fountain, vomit , drink vodka, hug. A wonderful tradition. Unfortunately, most of them were expended in the first few days of the special military operation. Very few are still left to swim in the fountain on August 2nd and mostly without a limb or two. The fountain at the shopping mall has no ramp.

Answer: Artificial intelligence has already taken up it's significant place in the digital world. AI is continuing to be one of the new technology trends for it's superiority in image and speech recognition, personal assistance in smartphones, navigation & ride-sharing apps etc. Apart from it, AI is also observed to be used in analyzing interactions to know connections and insights and to detect the changing patterns of customer behaviour by analyzing data in real-time, generating revenues and enhanced personalized experiences. With the rapid increase in usage of AI, it is expArtificial intelligence has already taken up it's significant place in the digital world. AI is continuing to be one of the new technology trends for it's superiority in image and speech recognition, personal assistance in smartphones, navigation & ride-sharing apps etc. Apart from it, AI is also observed to be used in analyzing interactions to know connections and insights and to detect the changing patterns of customer behaviour by analyzing data in real-time, generating revenues and enhanced personalized experiences. With the rapid increase in usage of AI, it is expected that the AI market will grow to a $190 billion industry by 2025 as AI systems are now reaching around $57 billion in 2021.2These forms of technologies will be further integrated in our life enormously by 2021. AR and VR are known to have enormous potential in entertainment. training, marketing and also in rehabilitation after an injury. They can also be used to train doctors for surgery. It is observed that around 14 million AR and VR devices were sold out in the year 2019. Now this global AR and VR market is expected to grow to $209.2 billion by 2022, by creating more opportunities in the latest trending technology.3.5G is considered as a revolutionary technology trend for 2021. Where 3G and 4G technologies are conquering the internet for browsing, by 2021, 5G is expected to dominate the digital world. The 5G services rely on advanced technologies like AR and VR, also cloud based gaming services such as Google Stadia, NVidia GeForce Now and much more. It is more likely to be used in HD cameras to improve safety and traffic management. Most of the telecom companies like Verizon, T-Mobile, Apple, Nokia Corp, QUALCOMM are actively working on 5G services. It is expected to be in the market world wide by the end of 2021.

Answer: The remarkable thing about Quora is that they don't charge us to participate.Did you ever notice how freely people post extremely helpful websites? Years ago, when the web was first created, I wanted some lyrics from Disney songs.  I was amazed to learn that someone had gone to the trouble of posting them, for free.  It had been a lot of work. Why did they bother?I began to realize that the web offered a new venue for a natural human spirit of generosity, of sharing. People love to help others. It is a very deep instinct, and probably more responsible for our civilization than is generally rThe remarkable thing about Quora is that they don't charge us to participate.Did you ever notice how freely people post extremely helpful websites? Years ago, when the web was first created, I wanted some lyrics from Disney songs.  I was amazed to learn that someone had gone to the trouble of posting them, for free.  It had been a lot of work. Why did they bother?I began to realize that the web offered a new venue for a natural human spirit of generosity, of sharing. People love to help others. It is a very deep instinct, and probably more responsible for our civilization than is generally recognized.  We gain pleasure when we do it.Wikipedia is also such a miracle. It is amazing how good a job it does. I grew up with the Encyclopedia Brittanica, and Wikipedia goes so far beyond it that it is amazing.  Many people contribute to improving the Wikipedia web sites, just out of the pleasure they get in doing a good thing, in helping to create something so well-done. Jimmy Wales should be given a Nobel Peace Prize.Quora, in my mind, is the latest discovery of a method to extend this instinct to help others. I am addicted. If I have the right answer to a question, I really enjoy sharing it. Unlike email, Quora shares the questions and answers with thousands of other people. In fact, many people don't even realize that they have a question until they see someone else posting it.

Answer: Right now, the code is mostly Python and JavaScript.  We use the Pylons framework as a starting point but have replaced about half of it with our own custom systems (LiveNode/webnode2.)  The JavaScript part of our infrastructure is built on top of jQuery.We use Thrift to communicate between different backend systems.Our main webserver is paste (the default for Pylons) with nginx and HAProxy in front of it.  For our Comet server, we use Tornado.We mostly use Amazon EC2 and S3 for hosting.Our data store is mostly MySQL + memcached right now, plus two services written in C++.We use git for versiRight now, the code is mostly Python and JavaScript.  We use the Pylons framework as a starting point but have replaced about half of it with our own custom systems (LiveNode/webnode2.)  The JavaScript part of our infrastructure is built on top of jQuery.We use Thrift to communicate between different backend systems.Our main webserver is paste (the default for Pylons) with nginx and HAProxy in front of it.  For our Comet server, we use Tornado.We mostly use Amazon EC2 and S3 for hosting.Our data store is mostly MySQL + memcached right now, plus two services written in C++.We use git for version control.

Answer: The exact details are complicated and are going to change as we improve our systems, but the principles, as of Feb 5, 2011 are:Answers with more upvotes are ranked higher.The exact details are complicated and are going to change as we improve our systems, but the principles, as of Feb 5, 2011 are:Answers with more upvotes are ranked higher.Anonymous answers count for this, too.Basically, if you want your votes to have more weight, the best thing to do is to write good answers. Writing really great answers will help even more, but writing helpful, normal answers never hurts, unless they are bad (collapsed).

Answer: It's a service written in C++ designed to be fast and designed for prefix matching. Normally autocomplete interfaces on websites are backed by database queries, or by search engines like Sphinx or Lucene that weren't originally designed for prefix matching or designed for speed, which makes them slower. We use the Pylons framework as a starting point but have replaced about half of it with our own custom systems (LiveNode/webnode2.) The JavaScript part of our infrastructure is built on top of jQuery.We use Thrift to communicate between different backend systems.Our main webserver is paste (the default for Pylons) with nginx and HAProxy in front of it. For our Comet server, we use Tornado.We mostly use Amazon EC2 and S3 for hosting.Our data store is mostly MySQL + memcached right now, pQuoting on of the co-founder of Quora, Charlie Cheever,“Right now, the code is mostly Python and JavaScript. We use the Pylons framework as a starting point but have replaced about half of it with our own custom systems (LiveNode/webnode2.) The JavaScript part of our infrastructure is built on top of jQuery.We use Thrift to communicate between different backend systems.Our main webserver is paste (the default for Pylons) with nginx and HAProxy in front of it. For our Comet server, we use Tornado.We mostly use Amazon EC2 and S3 for hosting.Our data store is mostly MySQL + memcached right now, plus two services written in C++.We use git for version control.”
